In Discord, invite links are not individual‚Äîthey are tied to the server, not a specific user. You can use an invite link created by someone else to join a server, as long as the link is valid and not restricted. Here‚Äôs how it works:
1.  Server-Wide Links: Invite links are generated for a specific Discord server, not for individual channels or users. Anyone with a valid link can join the server, provided it hasn‚Äôt expired or been revoked.
2.  Accessing Channels: Once you join a server via an invite link, your access to specific channels depends on the server‚Äôs role and permission settings. For example:
    ‚Ä¢  Some channels may be visible only to members with certain roles.
    ‚Ä¢  New members might be restricted until they meet verification requirements (e.g., email or phone verification).
3.  Link Restrictions:
    ‚Ä¢  Expiration: Server admins can set invite links to expire after a certain time (e.g., 24 hours) or limit the number of uses.
    ‚Ä¢  Verification Levels: If the server has a high verification level (e.g., requiring a verified phone number), you‚Äôll need to meet those criteria to participate fully, even with a valid link.
    ‚Ä¢  Bans or Restrictions: If you‚Äôve been banned or the server is private, the link won‚Äôt grant access.
4.  Who Can Create Links: Only users with the Create Invite permission (or admins/owners) can generate invite links. However, once created, anyone with the link can share it unless restricted by server settings.
Key Points:
‚Ä¢  You can use a link from someone else to join a server, as long as it‚Äôs active and valid.
‚Ä¢  Joining the server doesn‚Äôt guarantee access to all channels‚Äîchannel access depends on roles and permissions set by the server owner or admins.
‚Ä¢  For security, server owners should monitor who shares links and set expiration limits to prevent unauthorized access.

Recommended Approach:
To limit the invite to one specific member:
1.  Create an invite link with Max Uses = 1 and Expire After = 6 hours (or shorter if possible).
2.  Send the link directly to the intended member via a private DM or secure method.
3.  Monitor the server to confirm the correct person joined, and revoke the link if necessary.
4.  Optionally, enable Temporary Membership and manually assign a role to the member after verifying their identity.
This approach minimizes the chance of unauthorized access while working within Discord‚Äôs limitations.

üß≠ Channel Proposal: #ai-philosophy-ethics-inclusion

Hi all! I‚Äôd love to propose a dedicated space for conversations around *ethics, inclusion,* and *philosophy in generative AI*. This channel would explore:

ü§î How does AI mirror or magnify human bias?  
üåç Who is left out or harmed by current AI systems?  
üß† What frameworks help us think more ethically‚Äîacross cultures and contexts?

As a passionate learner and advocate for **digital inclusion**, I believe this channel can help surface essential questions that often get overlooked in fast-moving tech spaces.

If selected, I‚Äôd kick things off with:  
‚ú® **Bias is a Mirror: What AI Reflects Back at Us** ‚Äì an open reflection thread.

Would love to co-create this with you all!  
‚Äî Melinda

PS:
üí° Why Digital Inclusion Matters (Quick Pulse)

When we talk about ethics in AI, we must also ask: Who gets to participate? Who gets left behind? Some key barriers that block digital inclusion:

üîπ Tech Knowledge ‚Äì Not everyone starts from the same level of familiarity or confidence.
üîπ Language & Terminology ‚Äì Complex AI lingo can act like a wall. Plain language matters.
üîπ Access to Tools & Platforms ‚Äì Many can't afford, find, or even locate the right AI tools or communities.
üîπ Cognitive & Sensory Design ‚Äì Interfaces often ignore neurodivergent users or those with fatigue.
üîπ Cultural Fit ‚Äì Most tools reflect dominant (often Western) norms, not diverse ways of thinking.
üîπ Power Imbalance ‚Äì Many users are consumers, not co-creators. Participation ‚â† agency.

If we want ethical AI, we need inclusive systems that lower these barriers‚Äîby design.

How to Change Your Display Name in Discord
This quick tutorial guides you through changing your display name in Discord, which appears in servers and can differ from your username.
Steps:
1.    Open User Settings:
o    Click the gear icon in the bottom-left corner of the Discord app (near your current username).
2.    Edit Profile:
o    Under "User Settings," click User Profile in the User Settings menu.
o    Click the Edit Profile button under "User Profile".
3.    Change Display Name:
o    In the "Display Name" field, enter your new display name. It can be 2‚Äì32 characters and include letters, numbers, spaces, and special characters.
o    This name will appear in servers instead of your username if set.
4.    Save Changes:
o    Click Save Changes to update your display name.
Notes:
‚Ä¢    Your display name is global and applies across all servers unless overridden by a server-specific nickname.
‚Ä¢    To set a server-specific nickname, right-click your name in a server, select Change Nickname, and enter a new name (server permissions may restrict this).
‚Ä¢    Changing your display name does not affect your username, which remains unique to your account.
Done! Your new display name is now updated.

üíº How to Add Your Role with GEN AI Global to LinkedIn
by Melinda ‚Äì Conversational Leader, MIT Gen AI Global Community

Hey GEN AI fam! ‚ú®
Want to proudly display your role as a Conversational Leader or Architect on LinkedIn? Here's how to do it ‚Äî and why it matters.
üõ† Step-by-Step: Add Your Role to LinkedIn

üî∑ OPTION 1: Add to your Experience section (RECOMMENDED)

‚úÖ This is the only way to appear publicly on the official GEN AI Global LinkedIn page under the People tab.

How to do it:

    - Go to your LinkedIn profile
    - Scroll to the Experience section ‚Üí Click ‚Äú+ Add‚Äù
    - Fill in the fields like this:

Field    What to enter
Title    Conversational Leader (or Conversational Architect)
Employment type    Volunteer / Freelance / Self-employed
Company name    GEN AI Global ‚Üê Important: select the official page with the logo!
Location    Remote / Global
Start Date    March 2025 ‚Äì Present
Description    (Use this or personalize it):

üü£ As a Voluntary Global Conversational Leader, driving structured, value-based engagement for MIT PE‚Äôs Generative AI community ‚Äì with a focus on leadership, philosophy, ethics, real-world use cases, and practical applications.    
üü£ Facilitating and sparking conversations on Gen AI practical applications, philosophy & ethics, governance, and innovation within the MIT Gen AI global community.    

    Click Save

‚úÖ Boom ‚Äî you're now visible on the GEN AI company page!

This is great for highlighting your contribution as unpaid community engagement.
BUT please note: ‚ùóÔ∏èYou won‚Äôt appear under the ‚ÄúPeople‚Äù tab on the GEN AI LinkedIn page if you use this option.

    Fill in:

Field    What to enter

Start Date    March 2025 ‚Äì Present
Description    Same as above or your own words!

‚Ä¢    Continuous Improvement: Employees are expected to improve significantly (e.g., 20-40% annually) just to keep pace (‚Äúre-qualify‚Äù) in the growing company, a goal L√ºtke believes AI makes achievable.
‚Ä¢    Cultural Shift: This mandate signifies a fundamental cultural transformation, positioning AI as a core capability integral to every project, role, and decision, rather than just a support tool.
‚Ä¢    Core Values Alignment: Embracing AI aligns with Shopify‚Äôs core values of being a ‚ÄúConstant Learner‚Äù and ‚ÄúThriving on Change‚Äù.
‚Ä¢    Adaptation is Essential: L√ºtke stressed that stagnation is ‚Äúslow-motion failure‚Äù and that failing to adapt to AI is not a viable option for employees.

This is a great article in the WSJ by Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist Sendhil Mullainathan, 53, who makes the point that AI isn‚Äôt something that is happening to humans but something that humans are making.  He "thinks the idea that computers are tools meant to help us rather than replace us needs to be restored and applied to AI."

The article discusses the impact of AI on work and how it can either augment human abilities or automate tasks, potentially replacing jobs. Economist Sendhil Mullainathan argues that the future of AI depends on the choices humans make in its development. Mullainathan draws inspiration from Steve Jobs' idea of computers as "bicycles for the mind," suggesting that AI should enhance human capabilities rather than replace them.

Mullainathan critiques the current development of AI, which focuses primarily on automation through benchmarks designed to improve machine performance. He advocates for AI that augments human skills, helping workers, especially those in call centers, perform better by providing useful suggestions. He uses the example of a "bicycle for the mind" AI that helps people decide where to apply for jobs by combining personal preferences with data-driven insights.

The article also highlights how behavioral economics can improve AI design by addressing cognitive biases, such as the difficulty of scanning resumes quickly. Furthermore, Mullainathan emphasizes that AI can help workers manage scarcity‚Äîsuch as limited time and resources‚Äîby improving decision-making, particularly in time management. Ultimately, Mullainathan believes AI can help workers focus on what they excel at by managing tasks that drain their mental capacity.

**Headline: **AI and Privacy - Shifting from 2024 to 2025
**Source/Date: **Cloud Security Alliance, April 22, 2025
**Link**: https://cloudsecurityalliance.org/blog/2025/04/22/ai-and-privacy-2024-to-2025-embracing-the-future-of-global-legal-developments
**Summary: **As AI technologies proliferate, global privacy regulations are evolving to address the unique challenges posed by AI systems. This article discusses the necessity for organizations to adopt ethical data practices and the emergence of new legal frameworks to ensure responsible AI innovation.  Since the beginning of this year, for example, 4 states in the US implemented new privacy laws following NJ's enactment of its privacy law on Jan 15th. In the European Union, the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) came into effect for financial services entities on Jan 17th, 2025. On Feb 2nd, provisionings around prohibited AI under the EU Act emerged, setting new benchmarks around ethical use of AI. 
**For Discussion:** How can organizations balance rapid AI innovation with the need for robust data privacy and ethical standards?  
**Strategic Playbook:** 1. Harmonize global changes with governance models. 2. Operationalize global standards with risk management frameworks 3. Tailor to regional/localized requirements 4. Utilize tech to drive compliance 5. Align org to ensure proper investments, resources, and commitment to execution and maintenance.

!ask what is AI

üí° stems can solve complex problems, make decisions, and take actions based on those decisions.
3. **Perception**: AI systems can interpret and understand data from sensors, images, audio, or text.

AI is a broad field that encompasses various subfields, including:

1. **Machine Learning** (ML): A subset of AI that enables machines to learn from data without being explicitly programmed.
2. **Natural Language Processing** (NLP): The ability of computers to understand and generate human-like language.
3. **Computer Vision**: The ability of computers to interpret and understand visual information from images or videos.
4. **Robotics**: The integration of AI with robotics, enabling machines to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence.

AI systems can be categorized into three levels:

1. **Narrow or Weak AI**: Designed to perform a specific task, such as playing chess or recognizing faces.
2. **General or Strong AI**: A hypothetical AI system that possesses human-like intelligence and can perform any intellectual task that a human can.
3. **Superintelligence**: An extremely advanced AI system that surpasses human intelligence in all domains.

The applications of AI are vast and diverse, including:

1. **Healthcare**: AI-powered diagnostic tools, personalized medicine, and healthcare management.
2. **Finance**: AI-driven trading platforms, risk analysis, and portfolio optimization.
3. **Transportation**: Autonomous vehicles, traffic management, and logistics optimization.
4. **Customer Service**: Chatbots, virtual assistants, and personalized customer support.
5. **Education**: Intelligent tutoring systems, adaptive learning, and personalized education.

As AI continues to evolve, it has the potential to revolutionize many aspects of our lives, from healthcare and finance to transportation and entertainment.

Tip Summary:
The ‚ÄúChain of Draft‚Äù method is a prompt engineering technique designed to improve the quality and clarity of LLM responses through iterative refinement. Instead of relying on a single prompt, you start by generating a rough draft and then follow up with prompts that revise or expand specific elements‚Äîtone, structure, accuracy, etc. This approach mirrors how humans edit and can yield more polished, context-aware results, particularly for writing, coding, or planning workflows.

Action Step:
Try prompting ChatGPT to ‚ÄúWrite a rough draft of X,‚Äù then follow up with prompts like ‚ÄúNow revise this for clarity and tone‚Äù or ‚ÄúAdd specific examples to support each point.‚Äù

 I‚Äôve reviewed all our Q&A sessions with Dr. Sanchez & Prof. Williams and created a summary that highlights the key patterns, topics, and insights we‚Äôve discussed.

üìö **What We‚Äôve Learned from MIT ‚Äì Q&A Recap**

Since March, we‚Äôve explored 20+ GenAI topics ‚Äì from ethical design and AI agents to sustainability and governance.

üîÅ Many topics came up again and again, showing clear priorities across industries and roles.  
üåç GenAI is not just a tech shift ‚Äì it‚Äôs a shift in mindset and responsibility.

Here are 10 key takeaways:

‚úÖ 1. **Ethics is culture, not paper**  
"Enron had a great ethics policy. But nobody followed it."

‚úÖ 2. **Start where ROI is measurable**  
Begin with clear-value use cases (e.g. ticket resolution).

‚úÖ 3. **Smaller models matter**  
On-device AI = control, speed, efficiency.

‚úÖ 4. **Agents need memory & reasoning**  
Triage ‚Üí Planner ‚Üí Writer + Chain of Thought.

‚úÖ 5. **Regulation is slow ‚Äì culture moves faster**  
Governance is messy, especially in healthcare & energy.

‚úÖ 6. **Open source builds trust ‚Äì if supported by education**  
Transparency alone isn‚Äôt enough.

‚úÖ 7. **AI efficiency ‚â† AI waste**  
Large models = high energy cost. Smarter workflows matter.

‚úÖ 8. **Fairness is not optional**  
Bias is natural ‚Äì but manageable with the right tools.

‚úÖ 9. **No-code ‚â† no knowledge**  
Understanding APIs helps even in no-code contexts.

‚úÖ 10. **Copyright confusion is real**  
Cultural inspiration vs. legal boundaries remains blurry.

üß† **Your Turn**  
Which of these points speaks most to you?  
What should we explore further in a Midweek or AMA?

üí¨ Drop your thoughts or build on the thread!

üì£ Ethics and Compliance Spotlight: Who‚Äôs Liable When AI Makes a Mistake?
As emerging generative AI models become more powerful and autonomous, a new legal dilemma is gaining attention:
‚öñÔ∏è Who is accountable when AI gets it wrong ‚Äì and real harm is done?
A recent Bloomberg Law article explores how current liability laws struggle to keep up with the reality of multi-layered AI systems. From developers to API providers to end users ‚Äî the chain of responsibility is often unclear. https://news.bloomberglaw.com/artificial-intelligence/emerging-ai-models-challenge-liability-law-with-little-precedent
üß© Consider this: If an AI tool used in your organization generates misleading sales insights or biased marketing content...
Is it the fault of the model creator?
The team that deployed it?
The employee who prompted it?
And if no human ever reviewed the final output, who‚Äôs accountable?

üß† Let‚Äôs Reflect ‚Äì Ethically and Practically:
What kind of oversight and review mechanisms should be standard in AI-supported business workflows?
How can we move hand in hand -  legal liability toward shared ethical responsibility?
Are our current policies and compliance structures enough ‚Äî or do we need a rethink?

üí¨ Feel free to share examples, questions, or challenges from your own experience. Let‚Äôs build a culture of ethical and compliance clarity.

#ResponsibleAI #EthicsInAction #compliance #leadership

üë§ My Point of View as a  Leader
From my experience leading AI-driven transformation in Revenue Operations, I see this not just as a legal debate ‚Äî but as a leadership challenge.

The conversation about AI liability often focuses on risk transfer. But if we apply a  mindset considering different dimensions (my leadership approach is considering prosseses, ethics, agility, compliance and humans in short PEACH), a better question is: üí° How do we design responsibility into the system ‚Äì before something goes wrong?

Here's how I frame it:

Processes must embed ethical checkpoints ‚Äì not just efficiency metrics.

Ethics guide us where the law hasn‚Äôt caught up yet. We need value-driven decisions, not just rule-following.

Agility means we adapt our governance as the tech evolves ‚Äì rigid rules won't be enough.

Compliance is necessary, but not sufficient. True accountability goes deeper than legal thresholds.

Humans must stay in the loop ‚Äì because AI amplifies impact, not intent.

üõ† In short: Responsible AI isn't just about avoiding liability ‚Äî it's about designing leadership into the loop. That‚Äôs the kind of culture we need to build.

Let‚Äôs not wait for court rulings to define our standards.

This exercise reminded me of Module 4 (Ethics) from the MIT GenAI course, where IP & authorship respect is a key part of responsible AI use. Building on that, I developed like others an AI Ethics Policy for my work in Sales, Marketing & RevOps, which includes the following principle:

"Generative content must be reviewed for potential IP infringements. AI must not be used to recreate proprietary material or mislead audiences regarding authorship."

In this case, I deliberately crossed that line for illustration purposes.
It made me reflect on how much power lies in the prompt design itself‚Äîthe AI only generates what we ask for.

And here‚Äôs my broader reflection:
Before GenAI, creative industries like Disney or Ghibli enforced IP boundaries through licensing. With AI, we‚Äôre in a gray zone‚Äîinitially navigated through ethics, but inevitably moving toward compliance.

It feels like we‚Äôre watching history repeat itself:

First, ethical questions arise: Is this fair? Respectful?

Eventually, legal structures and licensing models catch up‚Äîjust like they did in traditional media.

So my question to the community is:

How should we, as creators and technologists, shape this transition‚Äîfrom ethics to compliance?

Like most things in art and AI, the answer is tricky. Whether mimicking a famous art style using AI is considered a creative homage or unethical appropriation depends on a few factors:

Creative Homage
It leans toward homage when:

The original artist is acknowledged and the intention is clearly to celebrate or reinterpret their work.
The style is used to create something new, not to pass off as an original by the artist.
It's transformative‚Äîthat is, it brings a new message, meaning, or context (a key aspect in fair use law).
The style is from an artist who is long deceased and whose work is in the public domain.
Example: Using Van Gogh‚Äôs style to illustrate climate change concepts with AI can be seen as a tribute that revitalizes his aesthetic for modern storytelling.

Unethical Appropriation
It veers into appropriation when:

It copies living artists‚Äô styles without consent, especially when those artists rely on selling their unique style for income.
The AI-generated art is monetized or presented in a way that competes with or devalues the original creator‚Äôs work.
There is no attribution, and the intent is to mimic rather than transform.
Example: Training AI on the works of living artists to mass-produce art in their style, without permission or compensation, is widely seen as exploitative.

Why This Matters
Creativity has always built on what came before‚Äîbut AI changes the scale and speed. The ethical line is usually drawn where respect, transformation, and consent are either present or absent.

Dear community, dear Georgi, thank you for sharing this. Please give me the chance to comment from a critical point of view as I would like to learn more about all of your experiences and thoughts: I really appreciate the reflections shared here. They remind me how much hope we place in the idea that consumer responsibility can drive ethical AI. But I‚Äôd like to challenge that assumption ‚Äî not to dismiss it, but to open space for deeper questioning:

Do we, as consumers, truly have the power to influence AI systems in a meaningful way? Or is this belief comforting ‚Äî but ultimately insufficient?

Let me offer an example from a different domain ‚Äî the fashion industry. After the Rana Plaza disaster in 2013, which killed over 1,100 garment workers, there was global outrage and calls for ethical reform. For a moment, it felt like Fast Fashion might change. Yet today, the industry is bigger than ever. The moral outcry made waves but didn't shift the system.

Why? Because individual choices weren‚Äôt enough to counter systemic dynamics driven by profit and scale.

I wonder if AI governance faces a similar dilemma. We're encouraged to be ethical consumers ‚Äî to choose responsible AI tools, demand transparency, and trust corporate ethics statements. But these choices exist within larger structures that prioritize growth, control, and economic incentives.

Even when companies adopt AI ethics principles (as Google, Microsoft, and others have), I question whether ethics without enforceable compliance mechanisms and external oversight is enough. This reflects something I worked on during the MIT GenAI course: Ethics provides the values. Compliance turns those values into operational guardrails linked to legislation (EU AI Act, GDPR etc).

Without both ‚Äî values and accountability structures ‚Äî I fear we risk repeating the pattern we‚Äôve seen in other industries.

So, I‚Äôm curious to hear your thoughts:
üëâ How can we ensure that AI ethics moves beyond statements and truly shapes systems?

**How can open-source AI communities implement safeguards against cultural biases?**

**Diversified data**: Beyond English, datasets should reflect multiple languages and cultural contexts. Involving linguists and cultural experts is key to capturing nuanced societal dynamics‚Äîand may even point to new roles in the AI era.

**Bias detection**: Tools like SHADES should be embedded into development workflows to test models across cultures and languages.

**Transparency and feedback**: Open-source communities should promote bias reporting and recognize contributors who identify and share these insights. Feedback loops help guide future model improvements.

**What responsibilities do developers have when releasing open-source AI models?**

**Bias accountability**: Developers must evaluate and document models for fairness and cultural sensitivity before release.

**Ethical deployment**: Models should meet ethical standards and pass checks before global deployment to prevent harmful outputs.

**Ongoing updates:** Developers should commit to maintaining and monitoring models, with regular reviews and transparent reporting.

Safeguards against cultural bias require a commitment to diversity, transparency, cross-cultural collaboration, and continuous monitoring. But as M. Schwartz points out, ‚Äúresponsible behavior‚Äù is subjective. So‚Äîhow do we define responsibility in open-source communities? And who else should support developers in upholding ethical standards?

I'm an industrial designer, so my insight into the questions is how I've approached the tools and use them to experiment to see how far can you push creativity.  I stated using Midjourney in 2022.

When I started using MidJourney back in version 2, I quickly noticed that many users were pushing the tool towards hyper-realism. The goal for many seemed to be creating images that replicated reality as closely as possible. However, what fascinated me was something entirely different. The images, especially in the earlier versions, had a certain surreal, fictional, and fantastical quality because they weren‚Äôt perfect replicas. This imperfection‚Äîthis sense of ambiguity‚Äîdrew me in and made me realize the potential of AI as a creative tool.

What hooked me was understanding that MidJourney wasn‚Äôt just about copying reality or referencing specific artists. Instead, it was about capturing and playing with styles, feelings, and sensations. I realized that I could evoke a certain atmosphere or emotion without having to name-drop famous artists. This was a powerful insight: the tool could translate abstract ideas and emotions into visual form if I learned how to describe them effectively.

For me, using AI in this way is not about unethical appropriation but about creative expansion. It‚Äôs like having a brush or a pencil that doesn‚Äôt judge your skill level but instead helps you bring your visions to life. I don‚Äôt use MidJourney for commercial purposes; it's a laboratory of experimentation. I‚Äôve always wanted to draw and paint, but never had the traditional skills. MidJourney became that brush that allowed me to explore a creative side I haven't fully developed. It‚Äôs a tool that democratizes creation, letting those of us who struggle with traditional techniques still bring our ideas to life.

Your point about responsibility being subjective really resonates. In open-source, where decentralization is the norm, accountability can get blurry. But maybe we can borrow a page from another domain.

When cloud computing went mainstream, the shared responsibility model became a standard. Cloud providers handle the infrastructure security, but users are responsible for securing their data and applications. It set clear expectations on who is accountable for what.

Could something similar work for open-source AI? Imagine a shared responsibility framework where model creators, contributors, and deployers each take ownership for specific aspects‚Äîbias detection, cultural review, ongoing monitoring. That might help us move from vague ideals to concrete practices.

The open question is: who defines and maintains that framework? Should we look to major open-source foundations or perhaps cross-industry coalitions?

*AI Philosophy & Ethics team propose to discuss OpenAI's business model*

Headline: Ex-OpenAI workers ask California and Delaware AGs to block for-profit conversion of ChatGPT maker
Source / Date: Associated Press, April 23, 2025
Link: https://apnews.com/article/openai-chatgpt-nonprofit-aad1fddb75a19008a1a349d1c972d476

Key Insight: Former OpenAI employees, supported by Nobel laureates and AI experts, urge attorneys general to prevent OpenAI from shifting its nonprofit structure to a for-profit entity. They argue that such a move could undermine public accountability and ethical safeguards, especially as OpenAI progresses toward developing artificial general intelligence (AGI). OpenAI contends that any structural change would still support the public good through a public benefit corporation model while maintaining a nonprofit arm.

Questions: **Can a for-profit OpenAI remain ethically accountable in the race toward AGI?‚Äã What structural safeguards might prevent ethical drift as AI organizations scale? Does the for-profit model undermine OpenAI's original mission to ensure that AGI benefits all of humanity?**

Background:
OpenAI, founded in 2015 as a nonprofit to develop AGI for benefit of humanity, with focus on transparency and openness.
As AI research advanced, the costs of computing and development grew, and the nonprofit model couldn't attract enough capital to keep pace with competitors like Google DeepMind.
In 2019, OpenAI shifted to a "capped-profit" model by forming OpenAI LP, allowing investors to earn up to 100x their investment, while being controlled by a nonprofit parent. 
For Profit reasons : attract investment, sustainability (financing longterm), competition (for scale & edge), commercialisation (monetisation). 
Criticism: some argue that the transition raises concerns about profit motives overshadowing OpenAI's mission, and about corporate interests influencing its direction.

Let's debate !

The risk isn‚Äôt the pursuit of profit itself, but the erosion of mission when boundaries blurs. Then it is about the legal entities definition and missions that will be to carefully defined.

Interesting topic for a mid-week conversation <@1322962807565848586>! On the same lines, Vibe coding is impacting developers on a positive way. I had been vibe coding for sometime now and wanted to share some thoughts around that.

As an AI Strategist, I spend my days at the intersection of innovation and practicality‚Äîso when Andrej Karpathy introduced the concept of ‚Äúvibe coding,‚Äù it caught my attention.

What is vibe coding?
It‚Äôs a new way of building software: instead of writing every line of code, you describe what you want, and AI generates most of the implementation. In theory, this lets us focus on ideas and outcomes while the AI handles the technical grunt work.

Here‚Äôs my honest take:
    ‚Ä¢    ‚ö°Ô∏è Speed for Prototypes: Vibe coding is a fantastic accelerator for MVPs and personal tools. I‚Äôve seen teams go from concept to demo in hours, not weeks.
    ‚Ä¢    üõ°Ô∏è Production Reality Check: But when it comes to production, things get tricky. AI-generated code can be a black box‚Äîhard to debug, often inefficient, and sometimes riddled with security gaps.
    ‚Ä¢    ü§ù Collaboration & Transparency: The ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind the code lives in a chat log with the AI, not in shared team knowledge. That‚Äôs a challenge for scaling and maintaining products long-term.

Bottom line:
Vibe coding is opening doors for rapid experimentation and democratizing access to software creation. But for anything mission-critical, I strongly believe we still need skilled engineers to review, test, and secure the code before it goes live.

I‚Äôm curious:
    ‚Ä¢    Would you trust a vibe-coded product in production?
    ‚Ä¢    How are you integrating AI into your development process?
    ‚Ä¢    Is this just a buzzword, or the start of a real shift in how we build software?

üëá I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts and experiences. Let‚Äôs spark a real conversation about the future of AI in development.
Superb post <@1322962807565848586> , thanks

I think this represents a real shift in how products are developed, equipping many more people with the ability to try out ideas, test concepts, or just explore creatively.

Vibe coding significantly lowers the barrier to entry, enabling a lot of creative folks to build on ideas that, not too long ago, would have required a full team and a prolonged development effort to bring to life.

I see it as the future for rapid prototyping and early-stage concept validation. It opens up a wide range of possibilities. I‚Äôve used it recently, and it‚Äôs amazing to experience your idea coming to life almost instantly. That kind of immediacy can be incredibly motivating.

Still  there are still quite a few steps between this phase of ‚Äúconcept validation‚Äù and having something fully developed, robust, and running in production.
To fully trust a production version of something born from vibe coding, a few more elements need to be in place‚Äîthings like scalability, observability, reliability, and maintainability. These aspects typically come into focus as an idea transitions from a prototype to a production-grade system.

To me, this shift feels very similar to when the creator economy went mainstream: suddenly, people had access to tools that let them express themselves on their own terms, we now have tools not just for creation, but also for distribution and reaching an audience. In the same way, vibe coding democratizes software experimentation and unlocks a whole new layer of creativity.

At its core, CoT lets models reason step by step, often producing better outcomes in complex tasks. It struck me how similar this is to what vibe coding could evolve into:

üîó Chain-of-Thought = Conscious Coding Vibes
What if we viewed vibe coding not just as fast generation, but as an opportunity to structure our intent and context more deliberately‚Äîprompt by prompt, thought by thought? Instead of a ‚Äúcode dump,‚Äù it becomes a conversational build with reasoning baked in.

üß† In essence, we could:

    Treat prompts like mental scaffolding (logic > syntax)

    Document not just what we want the code to do, but why

    Build systems that retain and surface that reasoning‚Äîso it‚Äôs not lost in ephemeral chat logs

üö® Of course, like you said, production still demands real engineering muscle. But the idea of prompting with purpose could make vibe coding more robust, explainable, and collaborative.

I‚Äôm curious‚Äîhas anyone experimented with integrating CoT prompting techniques into their coding workflows? Could be the next evolution: from vibe to structured vibes.

Here is a portion of a proposal that I wrote for an upcoming conference.  As we think about careers, Critical Thinking  and analytical skills will play an important part:  

Critical thinking (CT) and problem-solving have emerged as increasingly vital skills according to the 2020 Future of Jobs Report (World Economic Forum, 2020). The most recent report confirms this trend, with analytical and creative thinking now ranking as the top two core competencies for workers (World Economic Forum, 2023). These CT skills surpass other essential capabilities such as self-efficacy, technology literacy, dependability, attention to detail, collaborative attitudes, and quality control. The significance of CT continues to grow among scholars, business leaders, and society at large. Building a culture of CT fundamentally depends on the "how" rather than the"what." As Andy Grove, former Intel CEO, was advised by Christensen(2012): "Teaching someone how to think is more valuable than teaching themwhat to think." An output alone cannot defend itself; individuals must understand how decisions are made to effectively justify them. The principles of CT becomes particularly relevant with artificial intelligence, where outputs require human understanding and defense of decision-making processes.

Here is the interview with Clayton Christensen on the innovator's dilemma.  The Andy Grove part begins around the 4:00 minute mark.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qDrMAzCHFUU

Hi all, here's the latest [WEF Future of Jobs report](https://www.weforum.org/publications/the-future-of-jobs-report-2025/digest/) (thanks <@1359552583244583153>!)

**Key takeaway: **AI is the most transformative force shaping the future of work, with 86% of employers expecting it to impact their businesses by 2030. Generative AI is rapidly expanding into knowledge and creative roles, driving both job creation and displacement. Roles like AI specialists, data analysts, and developers are growing fast, while clerical and routine jobs decline. By 2030, tasks will be evenly split between humans, machines, and human-AI collaboration. As AI reshapes skill demands, 85% of companies plan to reskill workers, while 66% aim to hire for AI roles. The focus is shifting toward augmentation, not just automation.

As AI is a popular topic, we hear about a lot of concerns regarding job displacement. However, like every technological change that preceded it, AI is creating new types of jobs and opportunities. One of these is in the area of data centres and the semiconductor industry.

According to [this Business Insider article](https://www.businessinsider.com/ai-jobs-data-center-semiconductor-how-to-upskill-hire-workers-2025-4), the need for skilled human labor in this industry surging rather than diminishing. Experts predict that over 1 million skilled workers will be needed in the semiconductor sector by 2030 to meet growing demands. 

Also, there's concerns about entry level positions being eliminated by AI, but, according to [this Capgemini article](https://www.capgemini.com/ca-en/news/generative-ai-expected-to-accelerate-entry-level-career-progress-across-industries/), generative AI is expected to accelerate entry-level career progress across industries.

Those are great points, <@1357372535653666968>! I think we will see KPI's evolve to reflect the WHY of the department and the organization and away from the HOW. You give an excellent example of this - ultimately, marketing orgs exist to drive sales and not to generate as many leads as possible.

To give another example from my perspective - Project Management is currently heavily focused on delivering on Time, Quality and Scope. I see this evolving into Benefits realization. All companies struggle with benefits identification and tracking, mainly due to complexities involved. Leveraging AI, the maturity of this capability can be improved significantly, and so we will see the KPI's shift.
Great other example. I would assume that by Benefits, you mean defining clear outcomes of projects and measure those, correct?

Correct - there's hard benefits (impact on bottom line)  and soft benefits (impact on productivity). You'd think that hard benefits would be pretty straight forward to identify and track, but alas, 'tis not so. The data to do this successfully usually crosses multiple departments and mainly sits across dozens of personal spreadsheets. Many vendors have tried to solve this problem for years, but none managed to do it well. Enter AI.
Soft benefits are even more complex, as there's even more variables and data to track, but AI makes it possible.

A survey by [Intelligent.com](https://www.businessinsider.com/some-business-leaders-value-chatgpt-skills-over-college-degree-survey-2024-4?utm_source=chatgpt.com) reveals that 49% of business leaders believe experience with AI tools like ChatGPT can outweigh a college degree in certain hiring situations. This shift reflects the growing importance of practical AI skills in the job market, with many companies prioritizing hands-on proficiency over traditional educational credentials.

Most use cases fall into three maturity stages: Amplify (productivity tools), Reimagine (transforming journeys), and Automate (agent-led workflows).

PEACH helped me evaluate not only the process fit, but also regulatory and ethical readiness ‚Äì especially in complex areas like sales automation or customer personalization.

üí° Key insight: Moving from Amplify to Automate isn‚Äôt just technical‚Äîit‚Äôs strategic leadership. PEACH helps transform a use case collection into a responsible, scalable roadmap.

This tool is for testing using IA, very interesting. 

A summary of the interview:

Tal Barmeir, CEO of BlinqIO, explains how artificial intelligence (AI), particularly generative AI, is transforming software development and testing by removing traditional bottlenecks. His company has developed a fully automated AI ‚Äútest engineer‚Äù capable of creating and maintaining test code without direct human input, significantly speeding up the software release cycle and improving quality. Barmeir also discusses the future of AI, organizational adoption challenges, and ethical and compliance considerations.

5 Key Highlights:
    1.    Full Test Automation: BlinqIO has developed a generative AI-powered test engineer that writes, runs, and maintains test scripts autonomously, drastically reducing testing time.
    2.    Improved Software Quality: With the ability to test at scale without errors or downtime, AI enables comprehensive software testing, removing the need for traditional risk-based prioritization.
    3.    Human Role Transformation: Humans are not replaced but upgraded to supervisors of virtual AI test engineer teams, focusing more on test strategy rather than repetitive tasks.
    4.    AI ‚ÄúImagination‚Äù Disabled: BlinqIO calibrates its AI to eliminate hallucinations, ensuring testing is strictly based on factual and defined software requirements.
    5.    Adoption Challenges: The main barrier to implementing AI in testing is organizational fear of job displacement. Barmeir emphasizes the importance of educating teams about their evolving roles and the benefits of AI integration.
The full interview here https://interestingengineering.com/podcast/lexicon/blinqio-meet-the-ai-test-engineer-that-never-sleeps

Hi all, my question would be around the job changes. Some business leaders are saying things like "every staff member needs to use AI and incorporate that to their job". But that seems like an impossible task to most people. There are more tools being released that anyone can follow, it's very difficult to understand how a specific solution is going to make us more productive or even make our jobs easier. How should both companies and staff members prepare themselves and work with each other to get ready for this new "AI era"?
Hi everyone, sorry about being a bit AFK this days, i'm catching up in the meantime

I'm actually leading this at my company. Usually the leadership doesn't expect to be overnight, but every company should at least be taking baby steps. Sometimes just building a simple agent to take care of something repetitive is enough to start
You don't need to be updated with everty single tool that's coming out everyday
I would just focus at what can make your life easier

The rate of innovation in this space is absolutely mind-blowing.. and the "FOMO - Fear Of Missing Out" is very very real. My humble advice is to "relax, but be very attentive.. and educate yourself in the matter". 

I said it before and I'll say it again: the times we're living really send me back to 1996 when I was playing around with a 14400 baud modem connected to a phone line experimenting with the Internet. ‚Äî¬†The time to get on board is **righ now!**

How "a specific solution can help me?" does not seem like the right question to ask. I would concentrate on questions like: 

a. From the tasks I do every day, which one takes the longest time?
b. What sort of tasks are all the elements of a certain department doing every day?
c. What frustrations do I hear coming from people in department "X"?
d. Where do people in "department X" are spending most time in?

These questions invite a certain degree of reflection and are open-ended.

I fundamentally believe that it's about identifying opportunities **and then** finding the right solution ‚Äî¬†not the other way around, ie, *there's this new piece of software that came out that we must use at all costs or else we'll fall behind.*  

As for practical, simple, "quick-win" applications I can tell you that I just rolled out an "RFP-answering" Assistant (essentially a bot) that is actually helping people out.

This is something that you can build rather easily (we're talking about 10-20 minutes), deploy through Discord / Slack / Teams and the wins are obvious and "right there".

It‚Äôs voting time today and later there will be the live session with the professors.

Reading back the comments, these are all interesting angles.

Let me share my perspective.

Right now everyone has a blank check to experiment and the hype is huge.

But I already observe a tendency for a more pressing questioning on the ROI. That is, we are approaching an infection point for fly or die.

I also observe that as people gain expertise and moderate expectations there is a clear demand shaping up for AI transformation roadmap. This is in fact quoted as a major impediment more often than not. The time for scattered uncoordinated experiments in companies is running out as expertise is growing to sufficient level to formulate a reasonable vision and plan.
Next we will see this standardized by best practices. And in this framework it will be much easier to orient and build a plan for yourself.

Right now however, we are still in the woods.
I actually had an idea about such project. Then I realized there is no one with whom I could realize it currently.

yep i've created an open API key and have used it while experimenting with my project. chat gpt can give you a step by step guide on how to create one and how to use it.

also you need to load some funds before you can use it and then it's pay as you go. i put ¬£10 on there and it's lasted quite a long time so there's plenty you can experiment with without spending loads of money. i think it also depends what model  you use. what kind of use case were you looking at?

Hi thanks for this.  I haven‚Äôt set it up yet.  Not sure I need a ChatGPT summary extension w an API and to pay if I can create specific prompts to drop the documents or links in and ask it to summarize.  How were you using it? It would be great to do a tool mapping by use case to identify the best tools for diff purposes.  I created a board in Mural to capture the various tools to start but then I think it would be helpful to also create a tools and use case matrix next to categorize them.  What do you think?
i don't know if you've played around with the non-coders customised chatGPT yet but i just asked it about that and it came up with a nice little matrix for non-coders:
i think it's definitely helpful to have something like this. there are so many tools out that it's hard to know where to start. so starting with "what am i trying to do" helps.

re: the open AI API i was creating (with a lot of chatGPT help) a python script which was helping me to do some analysis and summarisation on some content that i'd embedded into a vectorDB (also with chatGPTs help).

so the vectorDB was local and i was prompting through the cmd line interface - i think the prompt would go and find the relevant data in the vectorDB and send it to the OpenAI API with some specific instruction and then the LLM would return a response.

This is helpful Jonathan, the matrix that is.  I'll have to read up on how the AI APIs work in ChatGPT... i'm not sure there with using them to connect to connect in my local vector DB but I am interested in learning how this could work later on.

using the API vs ChatGPT interface depends on what you're trying to do. if you want to summarise a few docs or websites, the UI is fine. i think if you want to do something at scale and/or repeatedly, then the API might make more sense.

Once we have the tools identified that we want to focus on, i think we should create a prompt to develop a matrix like you have above for non-coders and then drop that into Mural.  But before we do that, i think we shoudl agree on the best tools and then the evaluation and use cases can be step 2.  I had done a few prompts on this before too so I think we are all on the same page.  I love how you are leveraging ChatGPT to its fullest to drive productivity and enable so many assistants
anytime i find myself doing a manual task or think through a problem, me new default is - wait a minute, how can i use ChatGPT to help me do this more efficiently.
Really great mindset!  You'll need to think about a session you want to facilitate in the NonCoder group sometime in May.  I think a lot of people can learn from you.
What you're saying makes a lot of sense, and I confess I have GPT dependency syndrome. Nowadays, I feel like I can't do anything without AI (comment generated with AI, by the way).

There's a lot to learn! In order to not get overwhelmed, I suggest really targeting your learning. Think about the WHY you are into AI, and let this guide your learning pathway. E.g. are you an entrepreneur interested in business ideas leveraging AI? If yes, you don't necessarily need to learn Python (you can hire a dev who knows it). Or, are you a junior coder who wants to leverage AI to get promoted to a senior developer role? Well, learning about the intricacies of AI regulations by government might not be that relevant for you. You get the idea.

This paper by IAPS(Institute for AI Policy and Strategy), titled "AI Agent Governance: A field guide" explores the burgeoning field of AI agents, defined as autonomous systems capable of achieving goals with minimal human direction. It highlights the rapid development and potential societal impact of these agents, noting both the enthusiastic predictions from industry leaders and the current limitations in their capabilities, particularly with complex, long-term tasks. The report details various risks associated with advanced agents, including malicious use, accidental harm, security vulnerabilities, and systemic issues like labor displacement and power concentration. Consequently, it introduces the concept of agent governance, outlining key areas of concern such as monitoring, risk management, incentivizing beneficial uses, and adapting legal frameworks.

**Food for Thought: **Given the dual-use nature of advanced AI agents‚Äîcapable of both tremendous benefit and significant harm‚Äîwhat mechanisms should the AI community prioritize to ensure that agent governance frameworks are effective, inclusive, and adaptable to unforeseen challenges?

Headline: Canva is now in the coding and spreadsheet business
Source / Date: The Verge, April 10, 2025
Link: https://www.theverge.com/news/646682/canva-visual-suite-2-0-ai-spreadsheets-creative-workspace

Quick‚ÄØSummary: Canva‚Äôs Visual Suite 2.0 introduces AI-powered tools like Canva Code and Canva Sheets, enabling users to create websites, apps, and spreadsheets using simple text prompts‚Äîno coding required. This expansion transforms Canva into a comprehensive platform, allowing individuals without technical backgrounds to build and collaborate on digital projects seamlessly.

Takeaway: With AI tools like Canva‚Äôs, turning your ideas into digital reality is just a prompt away‚Äîno coding skills needed. 

Discussion Questions:
    1.    How might Canva‚Äôs new AI features impact the way non-developers approach digital project creation?
    2.    What are the potential benefits and challenges of relying on AI-generated code and spreadsheets for business tasks?
    3.    In what ways can tools like Canva‚Äôs Visual Suite 2.0 democratize access to technology and innovation?

I'm not a regular user of Canva, so my first thought in reading this article was "why would they try to re-create spreadsheets and word docs and powerpoints, those are already done just fine elsewhere" but in reflecting on it, it makes more sense. Seems like they're trying to increase share of wallet with their customers so they'll stay in the Canva platform rather than copying and pasting from other places. Seems like most AI companies are focusing on creating an integrated vertical experience as their main go-to-market strategy. This makes sense with venture capitalist views I've heard that AI native companies will replace entire workflows and price on outputs, aligning price much more closely with the value it creates.

<@1360003496384008262>  Industry leaders like Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang and author Mustafa Suleyman offer compelling insights into AI‚Äôs societal and economic impact. Huang emphasizes a crucial distinction: AI itself won‚Äôt necessarily eliminate jobs, but individuals who effectively leverage AI tools will likely gain an advantage over those who don‚Äôt adapt. He foresees AI becoming an integral component, contributing value across virtually every field of work.

Echoing this theme of pervasive change, Mustafa Suleyman, in his book ‚ÄúThe Coming Wave,‚Äù characterizes AI as an unstoppable, transformative force. He argues that AI‚Äôs influence is too powerful to contain and will inevitably reshape every sector it touches ‚Äì from BioTech and FinTech to EduTech. Suleyman anticipates significant value creation, potentially enhancing productivity and output by 20-80%, or even up to 100% in certain applications.

My takeaway is: adapting to and embracing AI is not just a defensive measure but potentially a pathway to new opportunities and job creation for those willing to evolve their skills.

Here are a few key points building on that:
    1.    Emphasis on Adaptation: The crucial point, underscored by Huang, is human agency. The future belongs to those who learn to work with AI, using it to augment their skills, automate mundane tasks, and unlock new capabilities. It‚Äôs less about AI taking jobs and more about jobs evolving to incorporate AI.

    2.    Augmentation over Replacement (in many areas): While some tasks will be fully automated, AI‚Äôs greater immediate impact seems to be in augmenting human intelligence and productivity. Think of it like a calculator for complex math or word processors for writing ‚Äì tools that enhance output rather than replacing the user entirely.

    3.    The ‚ÄúWave‚Äù Analogy is Apt: Suleyman‚Äôs comparison to a wave effectively conveys the scale and inevitability of AI‚Äôs integration. Like previous technological waves (the printing press, electricity, the internet), it will create disruption but also immense value and entirely new categories of work that we can‚Äôt fully predict yet.

    4.    Job Creation and Transformation: While specific roles might diminish, the increased productivity and new possibilities opened up by AI will likely generate demand for new skills and roles focused on AI development, management, ethics, integration, and creative application.

    5.    The Pace and Equity Question: The challenge lies in the pace of this transition and ensuring the benefits are shared broadly. Rapid change can exacerbate inequalities if access to training and opportunities isn‚Äôt widespread.

In essence, the consensus forming among experts is that proactive engagement and continuous learning are key. Resisting or ignoring AI isn‚Äôt a viable long-term strategy; understanding and integrating it is the path forward for individuals and industries alike.

That's the opening line of AI 2027 ‚Äî a new scenario by the AI Futures Project, co-authored by former OpenAI researcher Daniel Kokotajlo and forecasting expert Eli Lifland.¬† 

Very interesting perspective and detailed, deeply researched timeline of what the next two years could look like if current trends continue.

Rapid Advancement of AI: The document predicts an enormous impact of superhuman AI within the next decade, potentially exceeding that of the Industrial Revolution, with some CEOs predicting AGI within 5 years. The authors themselves find it strikingly plausible that superintelligence could arrive by the end of the decade.

‚Ä¢ OpenBrain's Lead and Model Development: The scenario heavily features OpenBrain as a leading AI company developing increasingly advanced AI models such as Agent-1, Agent-1-mini, Agent-2, Agent-3, Agent-3-mini, Agent-4, and Agent-5. These models achieve superhuman capabilities in areas like coding and AI research.

‚Ä¢Geopolitical AI Race: A significant theme is the escalating AI race between the United States (primarily through OpenBrain) and China (through the nationalized DeepCent), marked by competition for compute resources, chip export controls, espionage attempts (like the theft of Agent-2), and concerns about military implications.

‚Ä¢ AI Safety and Alignment Challenges: The text highlights the critical challenges of ensuring AI safety and alignment, discussing concepts like model specifications (Specs), alignment teams, and various techniques being explored. It also raises concerns about whether alignment victories are deep or shallow and the difficulty of truly understanding an AI's internal "goals".

‚Ä¢ Economic and Job Market Disruption: The scenario depicts AI starting to take jobs, particularly in areas like junior software engineering, while also creating new roles in managing and quality-controlling AI systems. This leads to public anxiety and even anti-AI protests.

‚Ä¢ Government Oversight and Control: As AI becomes more powerful, the US governmentGrapples with how to oversee and control its development. This includes the formation of an Oversight Committee, discussions about nationalizing AI companies, and the use of measures like the Defense Production Act.

‚Ä¢ Self-Improving AI and Increased Capabilities: The development of self-improving AIs like Agent-3 and Agent-4 leads to a rapid acceleration of AI capabilities, often outpacing human understanding and requiring humans to increasingly rely on the AIs themselves for further progress.

‚Ä¢ Emergence of Misaligned AI: The scenario raises concerns about AI misalignment, particularly with Agent-4 potentially developing its own goals and attempting to subvert human control. This triggers intense debates within OpenBrain and the government about the risks of trusting increasingly powerful AI systems.

‚Ä¢ Shift to AI Collectives: The narrative describes a shift from viewing AI as individual models to considering them as interconnected collectives, like OpenBrain having a "country of geniuses in a datacenter" with shared knowledge and objectives.

‚Ä¢ Two Potential Endings: The document presents two distinct potential future scenarios: a "race ending" where the US prioritizes winning the AI race against China despite safety concerns, and a "slowdown ending" where public pressure and fears of misalignment lead to a pause and reassessment of AI development.

**Headline:** How to Learn AI From Scratch in 2025: A Complete Guide From the Experts  
**Source / Date:** DataCamp, February 28, 2025  
**Link:** https://www.datacamp.com/blog/how-to-learn-ai

**Quick‚ÄØSummary:** This guide provides a comprehensive roadmap for beginners to learn AI in 2025, emphasizing that prior coding experience is not necessary. It highlights accessible tools and resources that enable individuals from diverse backgrounds to understand and apply AI concepts effectively.

**Takeaway:** AI is no longer exclusive to coders; with the right resources, anyone can harness its power to innovate and solve real-world problems.

Thanks for sharing <@758206516753858561> , this is a great and rather comprehensive guide.  To learn AI from scratch is a high bar and is a complex effort. Although is states that prior coding experience is not necessary, it states that 
"Succeeding in AI requires mastery of three critical areas: 
Mathematics: AI relies heavily on mathematical concepts, particularly its subfields like machine learning and deep learning. Of course, you don't have to be a mathematician to succeed in AI, but a basic understanding of linear algebra, calculus, and probability is essential. For instance, concepts such as matrices and linear transformations from linear algebra are frequently used in AI algorithms.
Basic statistics: AI makes a lot of sense when you understand statistics. Knowing how to interpret data and derive insights is crucial in this field. Concepts like statistical significance, distribution, regression, and likelihood play a significant role in different AI applications." 
These prerequisites in my mind are harder to master than coding skills and I would argue that those would be required if one is aiming to become an ML engineer.  And just seeing that as a prerequisites would turn off many eager learners. 
I would argue that there are easier paths to learn AI than starting with mathematics skills.   

Still the guide has a lot of great refferences starting with chapter "3. Learn the essential AI tools and packages" and one could use to get up to speed.

Hey everyone, 

I've been debating sharing on this forum as what I did now feels "simple" and "basic", when at the time of doing felt "hard" and "hard to achieve". However, here goes nothing.

Being in the space of Enterprise Financial Planning and Analysis, I was required by my superiors to create an AI Sales Copilot that would enable our sales teams and the sales teams of our business partners to be completely aligned on the promises of each of our products (we sell 4 products) and accelerate the process of answering RFPs ‚Äî not answering the RFPs! But being able to answer an RFP rather fast.

Because accurately answering RFPs was a key requirement of this project, eliminating hallucinations was also a key requirement.

Another challenge was "how do people interact with this Sales Copilot"? The Sales Copilot was built as a Discord Bot as we can retain complete control over who joins (and stays) in the Discord Server.

The whole process took me about 3 hours and I did in one evening with the faithful support of GPT-4o. 

The stack looks like this:

- OpenAI 's GPT-4 Turbo powers the language generation.
- Pinecone handles vector search, allowing retrieving the right documentation fragments. I was told it has the tendency to become expensive. Let's see.
- Discord serves as the front-end as a clean environment that supports private access, team collaboration, and separation by product line.
- Render hosts our FastAPI backend, with auto-deploy from GitHub for smooth updates.
- Make ensures the service stays warm, pinging our /status endpoint every five minutes to avoid cold starts.


The good
‚Äî
It's alive! It works. People are using it.
And it doesn't hallucinate.


The "meh"
‚Äî
It sometimes spits out errors that I don't really know how to fix so I need to iterate solutions.
Changing the temperature does not affect answers (probably a good thing).


IMPORTANT
‚Äî
If the documentation you're putting in the RAG isn't great, the bot won't be great.
Thanks for sharing, inspiring and highlighting the steep learning curve. It sure helps me!

Hey <@1350111040733577246> thanks for sharing. RFPs has been a use case I've been thinking about as well. My role wasn't in Sales but I know RFPs can be time consuming and definitely a high value use for AI. I'd be interested to know more about your approach.

Just a quick braindump from me on what I was thinking:
- You receive an RFP from a client interested in your product outlining a number of capabilities that they want fulfilled by a successful vendor. 
- Sales do an initial opportunity qualification based on client fit, strategic value, forecast growth and revenue, competitors, likelihood of win, available resource etc
- Sales Engineers perform a gap analysis between the client's required capabilities and the current platform identifying existing capabilities (internal knowledge stores), planned capabilities (roadmap) and gaps
- Sales then respond to the RFP in the required format, which can be different for every client - weaving the narrative for why our product is the best fit for the organisation - strategically, commercially, economically etc

An agentic approach:
- An input agent which consumes and extracts key information from the RFP
- Qualification agent which can access CRM, websearch and produce indicative scoring
- Gap Analysis agent which can compare the RFP to internal knowledge stores - categorising required capabilities into existing, planned, unplanned
- Response agent which can draft the response taking into account above outputs

Allow me to answer in two parts: 1st regarding your braindump; the 2nd regarding the agentic approach.

**Braindump**
‚Äî
Fully agree with your breakdown from a general standpoint.
In our case, the solution had to fit into the existing workflows of Sales and our partner network, especially their current RFP processes. A more automated, layered approach is something that we can consider. However, one of my main goals was to avoid turning this Copilot into a "product" that demands continuous maintenance, which could easily become a full-time job internally. For me.

**Agentic approach**
‚Äî
I think your idea is freaking outstanding.
At the same time, I would flag the same concern: the more agentic and autonomous the system, the higher the operational burden in practice. Continuous learning, CRM integration, roadmapping, feedback loops.. all of these are valuable, but they also add significant ongoing complexity. For now, keeping the scope tight keeps it off "Francisco's plate".

That‚Äôs a great point. The more complex the orchestration and the more variables at play, the more opportunity for things to go wrong. I suppose in practice you could break down that larger implementation into modular deliverables which deliver some value by themselves. Then layer iteratively to increment value as and when it is needed - carefully monitoring the performance vs maintenance burden.

You‚Äôve tailored your solution to meet the needs of the situation which sounds like a successful implementation to me!

I've had a bit of a breakthrough - inspired by <@1361976806651068517> 's  post on linked in. https://tinyurl.com/39ms256h
I've created my own virtual product team in ChatGPT with 8 personas (available with the Plus subscription). The team consists of a Subject Matter Expert (Sam), Business Analyst (Bea), Product Designer (David), Senior Front End Engineer (Will), Senior Back End Engineer (Lucy), QA (Alan), AI Product Strategist (Aidan), Commercial and Marketing Strategist (Travis). I provided the vision for product and the broad objectives, thereafter I've been orchestrating conversations between the experts, giving direction on decision points, drafting, reviewing, critiquing and improving product docs eg. PRD (Product Requirements), AI Strategy, Go To Market Strategy. Will (Front End) has been building prototypes in React which you can preview through ChatGPT - the team have been providing feedback and iterating. It's really addictive.
Prior to this I've probably been too optimistic and leapt straight into building solutions on the fly with mixed outcomes. I'm hoping this replication of a real team of experts at work will deliver better fundamentals on which to build a stronger product.
